newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: CRICKET-AKRAM HITS CENTURY FOR PAKISTAN AGAINST ZIMBABWE.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-AKRAM HITS CENTURY FOR PAKISTAN AGAINST ZIMBABWE.

text.p: Pakistan captain
Wasim Akram completed his second test century in seven years and
shared a record-breaking stand with Saqlain Mushtaq on the third
day of the first cricket test against Zimbabwe on Saturday.
Akram was 122 not out and Pakistan were 368 for seven at
tea, just seven runs behind Zimbabwe's first innings total of
Akram and Saqlain Mushtaq (32) shared an unbroken
eighth-wicket stand of 131, beating the previous Pakistan record
for the wicket of 130 compiled by Hanif Mohammad and Asif Iqbal
against England at Lord's in 1967.
Pakistan added 75 runs to their lunch score of 293 for seven
after starting the day at 189 for six.
Akram achieved his century in grand style by hoisting
off-spinner Andrew Whittal into the main grandstand for his
fourth six.
He took 198 minutes and 162 balls to reach his hundred, his
first since he made 123 against Australia in Adelaide in the
1989-90 series.
The left-hander slammed 13 fours and and hit three of his
four sixes off leg-spinner Paul Strang, the best Zimbabwe bowler
with five wickets.
The only wicket to fall in the first two seassions was that
of Moin Khan, dismissed by Strang for 18.
Captain Alistair Campbell took the second new ball
immediately after lunch but it made no impact on the
well-established Pakistani pair.
